I tried dowload MSVC 1.40 from their website but I’m still getting that error Anyone knows a fix?
I got this same error after updating as well. +1
Update your inteliJ FRC plugin. Or wait for @Javaru to post an update

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Corretto JDKs do not work properly, due to their improper use of the MSVC runtime.

You somehow need to make whats running your code point to the WPILib installed JDK. VS Code does this automatically. For IntelliJ, theres a setting somewhere to change which JDK is used. For running from a command line, you need to make sure the WPILib JDK is higher up in path.
By selecting the jdk in C:\Users\Public\wpilib\2025\jdk in intellij, it worked. Thanks you everyone

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: Ive added an issue to my backlog for the IntelliJ IDEA FRC plugin to add a feature to pop-up a warning if a non WPI Lib JDK is in use (via the IDEs configuration) and to recommend using the JDK from the WPI Lib install. Thanks for the heads up @nstrike

link_counts.title: Warn about Corretto JDK use (#169) · Issues · Mark / IntelliJ IDEA FRC Plugin · GitLab

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Cool!

For more context for anyone else seeing this, one of the longstanding requirements of using the MSVC runtime is that the runtime must be equal to or newer then the newest library being executed.

In the past, this hasn’t really been used, but a change in the runtime last year actually took advantage of this requirement.

Most JDKs ship with an MSVC runtime, and many of them are old. Additionally, many of them don’t actually include the full runtime. Both of these are a problem for us, as all the JNI libraries loaded by WPILib both use a lot of the runtime, and are compiled against basically the newest runtime.

For the JDK we ship with WPILib, we patch in the newest runtime to ensure we don’t run into this issue. But we can’t easily do this for other JDKs. So this year, much more important than prior years, the WPILib JDK needs to be used.

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: Something that you might want to look into for next year is to have the WPI Lib JDK configured in the build via Gradle Toolchains . It would ensure that the WPI Lib is always used when running a Gradle task. It would likely require the definition of a custom toolchain resolver plugin . And the need to add a “ FRC year” to the Java version might not work in the Toolchain framework. Anyways, something to look into perhaps.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
I played with the Gradle Toolchains, and it doesn’t fix this problem. It changes what JDK is used to build, but not the JDK that gradle uses (and thus uses to run simulateJava).

Setting org.gradle.java.home does work, but it’s not something that can be done in the project gradle.properties in a platform-independent way, and doing it globally can mess up other things that use gradle. The WPILib VS Code plugin does do this by passing it as a parameter to gradle, and builds it based on the current platform.

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: Good to know. IntelliJ IDEA let’s you configure what JDK to use for running Gradle, separate from the JDK the IDE uses for the project. Not sure if I have access that setting via the plugin API to set it. I’ll have to look. I suspect that I can. At the very least, I can modify the Gradle run configurations my FRC plugin creates so they pass the parameter to Gradle like the WPI Lib VS plugin is doing. (And can put in an “on project load” check to update existing configurations.) Thanks for the info @Joe_Ross

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: Another (hacky) fix: rename the msvcp140.dll in the JDK directory to something else (I renamed it "!!!msvcp140.dll), so that the system MSVC runtime that you downloaded and installed gets used.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: I am not familiar with configuring Intellij; where do I got to change this?
